overview.title: Affordable Privacy Solutions
overview.content: Pressure-treated pine is the most popular fencing material in America, and for good reason. It offers traditional wood aesthetics at a fraction of the cost of premium materials like cedar or vinyl.
overview.additionalContent: Our treated wood fences use ACQ (Alkaline Copper Quaternary) treatment that protects against rot, decay, and insects. With proper maintenance, expect 15-20 years of reliable performance.

sections.title: Year 1
sections.content: DO NOT stain or seal for 6-12 months. The wood needs time to dry and cure after pressure treatment. Premature finishing will trap moisture and cause problems.

sections.title: After Curing
sections.content: Apply a quality exterior stain or sealer. Semi-transparent stains show wood grain while providing protection. Solid stains offer more color options.

sections.title: Ongoing
sections.content: Re-stain every 2-3 years depending on sun exposure and wear. Inspect annually for loose boards, hardware wear, and gate adjustment needs.

faqs.question: When can I stain my new pressure-treated fence?
faqs.answer: Wait 6-12 months before staining or sealing pressure-treated wood. The lumber needs time to dry and cure after treatment. Staining too early traps moisture and can cause peeling and wood damage.

faqs.question: How long does pressure-treated wood last?
faqs.answer: With proper maintenance (staining every 2-3 years), expect 15-20 years of service. The ACQ treatment protects against rot and insects, but wood still needs protection from UV damage and moisture.

faqs.question: Is pressure-treated wood safe?
faqs.answer: Yes. Modern ACQ (Alkaline Copper Quaternary) treatment replaced the older CCA (chromated copper arsenate) treatment in 2003. ACQ is considered safe for residential use and is approved for playground equipment.

faqs.question: Should I choose cedar or treated pine?
faqs.answer: Cedar costs more upfront but requires less maintenance and lasts longer (30-40 years vs 15-20). Treated pine is more budget-friendly but needs regular staining. We can show you both options at your estimate.
